isis.stitle: Recall 00501 - Bendix Antilock Traction Relay Valves (ATR-1 & AT-1) on 2574, 2674, 5000, 8100, 9100, 9100i, 9200, 9200i, 9400, 9400i, 9800, 9900, and 9900i models built from 3/29/99 through 5/31/99 with Navistar codes 04AZJ and 04091 or 04092

recall.subject: Bendix Antilock Traction Relay Valves (ATR-1 & AT-1) on 2574, 2674, 5000, 8100, 9100, 9100i, 9200, 9200i, 9400, 9400i, 9800, 9900, and 9900i models built from 3/29/99 through 5/31/99 with Navistar codes 04AZJ and 04091 or 04092

defect.para: Bendix supplied Antilock Traction Relay Valves were incorrectly assembled. An extra check valve was installed which will not allow the traction control system to function properly. The traction control system is designed to react to traction problems sensed at speeds less than 25 MPH. When the system detects a traction control event, the defective valve can cause the rear brakes to apply without warning and cause the vehicle to automatically come to a complete stop or experience complete rear wheel lock-up on slippery surfaces. If this happens, the rear brakes will not release until the air system pressure is depleted. An unexpected and uncontrollable application of the rear brakes could cause a vehicular accident, possibly resulting in property damage, personal injury, or death.
This campaign covers 2574, 2674, 5000, 8100, 9100, 9100i, 9200, 9200i, 9400, 9400i, 9800, 9900, and 9900i models built from 3/29/99 through 5/31/99 with Navistar brake codes 04AZJ and 04091 or 04092.

ownernote.para: Owners will be notified of this campaign on their vehicles by Navistar. During the recall process, a listing of owner names and addresses will be furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners and have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

para.emph: Before performing the service, please read and understand the following instructions completely.

warning.para: To prevent serious eye injury, ALWAYS wear safe eye protection when you perform vehicle maintenance or service.

Block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving. Support the vehicle with safety stands. Do not work under a vehicle supported only by jacks. Jacks can slip or fall over resulting in serious personal injury or death.

para.emph: Please read the following steps carefully before proceeding.
Important Notes To Read Before Beginning Service Procedure:

item.para: All of these valves are not defective. Please keep this in mind when ordering parts. An estimated 20% of the vehicles in this campaign have defective valves. Valves with a round sticker on top have already been inspected at the production plant and do not need to be replaced (see STEP 1 below).
The defective valves were built for nine days (March 29, 1999 to April 6, 1999). STEP 2 describes how to identify the defective valves.
There are two different Traction Control Relay Valve part numbers involved in this recall (see "Parts Information" section following this "Service Procedure").
Drain air system pressure before removing any air lines.

step1.para: Sticker inspection:Begin by visually inspecting the flat top of the valve for a round ¾ inch diameter sticker (usually painted over). It may be necessary to remove the valve from the frame and disconnect some air lines to be able to see the top of the valve. If this sticker is on the cover plate, return the vehicle to service because the valve has already been inspected at the assembly plant and the vehicle does not need a new valve (see FIGURE 1).

Build date inspection: If the valve did not have the round sticker the next step is to check the build date code on the valve to see if it was built on one of the nine suspect build dates (see TABLE 1 below). It may be necessary to remove some air lines and remove the valve from the frame to read the date code. Before removing any air lines drain the air system pressure. The defective valves were built from March 29, 1999 to April 6, 1999 and have build date codes as shown in the example in FIGURE 2 below. If the valve was built on a date shown in TABLE 1, proceed to STEP 3 and replace the valve.

svcproc.para: The location of the date code on the valve is shown in FIGURE 3 and FIGURE 4 below. Use a cleaning solvent, a rag and a good light to read the build date code. If the build date matches one of the nine dates in TABLE 1 above, change the valve. If the numbers cannot be read, proceed to STEP 3 and change the valve.

step2.para: Drain air system pressure if it wasn't drained during the inspection.
Mark the position of all the air lines and the electrical connections.
Disconnect the air lines from the ABS relay valve.
Remove the valve mounting nuts that hold the valve to the frame and remove the valve with the bracket attached.
Transfer all the fittings to the new valve.
Mount the new valve and reconnect all air lines and electrical connections.
Check the system for air leaks and proper operation.
VERY IMPORTANT! PLEASE MAKE SURE THESE VALVES GET RETURNED TO BENDIX (see instructions under the "PARTS INFORMATION" section below).

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified IMMEDIATELY from your dealer location.
Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.
However, consistent with the customer notification, dealers are expected to complete the repairs on the mutually agreed upon service date.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
